Authors: van der Velden, Peter G.; Setti, Ilaria; Bosmans, Mark W. G.; Muffels, Ruud J. A.
Article Title: Potentially Traumatic Events and Job Satisfaction A Prospective Population-Based Comparative Study
Abstract: Objective: The aim of this study was to examine the effects of potentially traumatic events (PTEs), posttraumatic stress symptoms (PTSS), and coping self-efficacy (CSE) on post-event job satisfaction. Methods: Repeated analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to assess differences in the course of job satisfaction during 1 year between population-based samples of affected and nonaffected workers. Multivariate regression analyses were conducted with pre-event health, job satisfaction and insecurity, and post-event PTSS and CSE as predictors. Results: About 16% of the affected workers had probable PTSD. The course of job satisfaction between affected (n = 123) and nonaffected workers (n = 644) did not differ significantly. PTSS and CSE did not independently predict post-event satisfaction, in contrast to pre-event job satisfaction. Conclusion: Findings suggest that when needed social support is provided, concerns about the negative effects of potentially traumatic events on job satisfaction could be somewhat relaxed.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study design lacks a control group as it only compares affected and nonaffected workers without a separate control group.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study does not address employment or labor outcomes and focuses on the effects of potentially traumatic events on job satisfaction.

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study does not meet the inclusion criteria as it focuses on potentially traumatic events and job satisfaction, not on employment or labor outcomes for people with mental health disorders.
